show_disparities_node.disparitiesPagetext: When population health or the quality of living environments varies by population characteristics such as income or race, there is disparity. One way to visualize disparity is to chart indicators of health or environment across levels of neighborhood poverty. We categorized neighborhoods as high, medium or low poverty. Then we took the median of the neighborhood-specific values in each category. The median is the middle of the sorted group of values.
show_disparities_node.indicator_name: Housing Safety: Adults Reporting Air Conditioning in the Home

info.info_name: Adults Reporting Air Conditioning in the Home
info.info_how_calculated: Estimated number of adults who reported having a functioning air conditioner in any room in their home, divided by the number of adults in the area; expressed as percent.
info.info_source: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

info.info_how_calculated: Neighborhoods are ranked according to the percent of people whose annual income falls below 100% of the federal poverty level. Rankings are then divided into 3 approximately equal groupings of low, medium and high poverty.

link_data_node.linkDataPagetext: The "Link Data" function shows associations between environmental health data at the neighborhood level using <a href="http://a816-dohbesp.nyc.gov/IndicatorPublic/Glossary.aspx?#Scatterplot" target="_blank">scatterplots.</a> The points represent x and y values for each NYC neighborhood. The pairs of indicators available for scatterplots were chosen because previous research suggests that one may either directly or indirectly cause or contribute to the other. Because the data being charted are <a href="http://a816-dohbesp.nyc.gov/IndicatorPublic/Glossary.aspx?#Ecological_Study" target="_blank">ecological</a> and not individual level, and because many factors contribute to the health of a population or environment, the patterns seen in these charts do not necessarily represent the underlying causal relationship.

Compare.graph_title: Neighborhood Housing Safety: Heat Stress Hospitalizations by Adults Reporting Air Conditioning in the Home
Compare.y_axis_title: Adults Reporting Air Conditioning in the Home - Percent 2007
Compare.x_axis_title: Heat Stress Hospitalizations - Estimated Annual Rate (per 100,000 residents) 2007

info.y_axis_title_reg: Adults Reporting Air Conditioning in the Home
info.info_how_calculated:
The number of NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of May-September for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded.  Data are based on date of admission and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. 

 

The numbers are divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates and expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

 

Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases admitted before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32.  Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data,United States Census

info.y_axis_title_reg: Adults Reporting Air Conditioning in the Home
info.info_how_calculated:
The number of NYC residents treated in a NYC emergency department (ED) during the months of May-September for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of visit and include those with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. 

  

Counts are divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates and expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

 

Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases occuring before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32.  Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data,United States Census
